description: Your ability to design user-centered experiences using core UX principles, flows, and usability heuristics.

scoreMeaning.strong: You systematically apply UX principles and design flows that cover all states and edge cases. You think problem-first, not screen-first.
scoreMeaning.decent: You understand UX basics and can create functional flows, but may miss edge cases or struggle with complex problem framing.
scoreMeaning.needsImprovement: You're still learning core UX concepts. You may jump to solutions before understanding problems, or miss important user states.

strong: Document your problem-framing process and share it with the team.
Create reusable flow templates for common patterns (onboarding, checkout, etc.).
Mentor juniors on wireframing and state mapping.
Contribute to design system documentation with UX rationale.
decent: Write a problem statement before starting each new feature.
Map all user states (loading, error, empty, success) for one key flow.
Review one existing flow and identify where it violates usability heuristics.
Practice explaining your design decisions using UX principles.
needsImprovement: Start each design with a one-sentence problem statement before opening Figma.
Learn the 10 usability heuristics and apply them to review existing products.
Practice sketching user flows on paper before designing screens.
Take a UX fundamentals course or read a foundational book.

examplesOfStrong: You propose research activities as part of planning, not as an afterthought.
You push back on risky assumptions with lightweight tests.
You create flow diagrams that include error states and edge cases.
examplesOfWeak: Features ship without any user touchpoints or validation.
Research is only done for big redesigns, not everyday work.
You design screens without considering the full user journey.
